            had a satisfactory outcome and moderate risk to development
            outcome. Both the Bank and the borrower performances were
            satisfactory. The main lessons learned were: 1. Stakeholder
            participation in project preparation and implementation is
            critical to achieving community-level impact. 2.  Education
            sector ability to generate good quality data is invaluable
            in increasing awareness about the problems and transparency
            in resolving the problems in education. 3. Equity-targeted
            interventions may have stronger impact if individual and

repnme.cdata!: A new spark in Romania's rural schools

abstracts.cdata!:
In the science lab which doubles as a
            classroom for 6th grade students, the desks are bulky white
            boxes behind which pupils sit two by two. Surrounded by
            potted plants and faded posters, the kids are dwarfed by the
            heavy wooden furniture. Carmen, a precocious 10 year-old,
            has to stand on her feet to reach her notebook and write.
            Upstairs, where lightweight desks and chairs have recently
            arrived, teachers like Vasile Priciu, 51, have discovered
            the art of semicircles and small study groups. Every morning
            the children of his stay engaged and interact, says the
            lifelong teacher, delightedly. This never happened in the
            past. Traditionally, school in Romania meant rows of
            children, often silent or bored, sitting distractedly as a
            teacher droned on with his or her lesson. In an effort to
            break with this passive model inherited from the countrys
            authoritarian past, the Romanian government is working with
            the World Bank to modernize its schools. A first set of
            projects helped revise the national curriculum, reorganize
            universities and rehabilitate school buildings. The latest
            endeavor, the Rural Education Project, was launched in 2003.
            Financed with a $60 million World Bank loan, the project
            seeks to correct disparities between rural and urban
            schools, a particularly important issue as Romania moves
            ahead with decentralization.

In the science lab which doubles as a
            classroom for sixth grade students, the desks are bulky
            white boxes behind which pupils sit two by two. Surrounded

            the heavy wooden furniture. A first set of projects helped
            revise the national curriculum, reorganize universities, and
            rehabilitate school buildings. The latest endeavor, the
            rural education project, was launched in 2003. Financed with
            a 60 million dollars World Bank loan, the project seeks to
            correct disparities between rural and urban schools, a
            particularly important issue as Romania moves ahead with
            decentralization. The ministry of education has earmarked 34
            million dollars under the rural education project to bring
            Romanias 1,500 rural schools up to civilized standards. The
            World Bank and the Romanian ministry of education also
            launched a competition in which schools, working with the
            municipality and local citizens, are invited to submit

            to discover the school library, for example, or offered

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the Rural
            Education Project for Romania is to have rural school
            students benefit from improved access to quality education,
            as evidenced by higher achievement scores and completion and
            transition rates. This wil be achieved through four project
            components. Component 1 improves teaching and learning by
            financing school-based professional development for
            teachers, providing career development opportunities;
            upgrading basic education conditions in schools, and
            ensuring access of rural students to basic teaching-learning
            materials. Component 2 improves school-community
            partnerships by setting up a school-community grants
            program. Component 3 strengthens the analytic capacity of
            the Ministry of Education and Research (MER) at national and
            local levels for policy analysis and formulation, as well as
            for planning and evaluation. Specifically, it establishes
            the National Education Indicators Set (NEI); improves the
            National Education Database (NED); and prepares a National
            Assessment of Basic Education. Component 4 strengthens
            project management capacity; its activities include forming
            an information, education, and communication strategy for
            increasing awareness of policy and decisionmakers and
            generating stakeholders' support. The project will
            support a broader community involvement in education
            management, working not only with education authorities, but
            also with the local councils, parents, and representatives
            of communities.

repnme.cdata!:
Romania - Rural Education Project :
            environmental management plan and environmental guidelines

abstracts.cdata!:
The environmental management plan for
            Romania's Rural Education Project identifies negative
            environmental impacts and proposed mitigation measures for
            most of the activities under the school rehabilitation
            sub-component. They are described as follows: Protect soil
            surfaces during construction, control and clean construction
            sites daily, and provide adequate waste disposal services to
            prevent soil contamination from waste materials. Dispose of
            oil and other hazardous materials properly, rehabilitate
            adequate sanitary facilities, and include appropriate
            disposal of wastewater and sewerage in order to avoid
            clogged drains and water quality decline. Use water to
            control dust and restrict construction to certain hours to
            reduce noise. To maintain aesthetics and protect the
            landscape and prevent debris from being dumped into water
            bodies, clean the building site and dispose of all debris
            and waste materials in accordance with clauses specified in
            the bills of quantities. Except for paint, all of the
            materials are non-hazardous. Sites used for construction
            waste disposal will be government-approved. Sites will be
            rehabilitated and trees planted. A community involvement
            measure calls for commitments from families and local
            businesses to look after trees. Finally, to prevent any
            health implications to populations, there will be specially
            designed systems for handling and disposing of hazardous
            wastes like asbestos.
